title: Monday, 7th October 2019

BE11:07am

Profit warning, leavened slightly by a couple of disposals, including the much discussed Air one.

BE11:07am

There was quite a lot of punter interest in SIG about the Air thingmy disposal ........

11:07 am
BE11:08am

........... which may well have resulted in some Scorchedfingers this morning.

PBateman morning all
BE11:10am

Let's get to the disposals in a minute. First, let's tackle the terrible October for slates in Germany and the UK.

PBateman snap poll.. deal/no deal/extension?
BE11:11am

Peel Hunt is shop, and restricted. They can summarise.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Weaker market conditions in UK distribution and Germany are resulting in a material cut to forecasts (15% for 2019). This disappointing news is tempered by the disposal of both the Air Handling business for c£198m and the Building Solutions business for c£38m. The disposal proceeds will be used to pay-off debt, factoring and return some cash to shareholders. The shares are trading on c12.6x PE revised 2020 estimates.

BE11:12am

And Stifel.

BE11:12am

The group has been reporting during the year a deterioration in the level of
construction activity in key markets, particularly the UK and Germany. This deterioration in trading
conditions has accelerated in recent weeks, and political and macro-economic uncertainty has
continued to increase. Management is taking ongoing actions to address the continuing market
weakness. Further benefits from transformation initiatives and the group's normal seasonality are
expected to deliver a stronger 2H.
Despite this, the recent further weakening of trading (e.g. UK Construction PMI 43.3 in September,
below 50 no-change level) as the group has entered its traditionally strongest months of the
year (c.30% of profit September/October) means the Board is now anticipating significantly lower
underlying profitability for the full year than its previous expectations (Stifel FY19E adj. PBT £74.2m,
post-IFRS 16). We note SIG is more exposed to commercial construction end-markets than UKlisted
merchant peers.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And Jefferies.

BE11:12am

Profit warning (c.£10-15m impact on 2019E PBT). SIG now guides to "significantly lower" profit expectations for 2019E due to poorer-than-expected September performance in the UK (both in Distribution and Exteriors) and Germany.
The lower profitability in these divisions is expected to be predominantly driven by sales reductions (which management believes is market-driven rather than company-specific), while there is limited change to the company's operating margin
assumptions. Management believes consensus forecasts would be sufficiently derisked if reduced by £10-15m for recent trading - September delivered around half of the budgeted profit, and such a magnitude of consensus adjustments would also imply a very difficult October (as flagged at the 1H19 results, SIG generates c.1/3 of annual profit in September, October and early November).

Ulster Pension Fund Morning all
BE11:13am

Okay ...... dumb question ..........

11:13 am
BE11:13am

If SIG makes a third of annual profit in September, October and early November, what are the roofers doing the rest of the time?

BE11:14am

I get why building repairs don't happen much in February, for instance, but that level of seasonality seems extreme.

BE11:14am

I should probably be asking a roofer. But I'd rather not.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Anyway, as to the disposals .........

BE11:15am

Back to Jefferies.

BE11:15am

Air Handling disposal (c.£20m impact on 2019E PBT). SIG has entered into an agreement to sell its Air Handling division to France Air, a family-run business seeking to consolidate in the space. The EV of £198.3m represents 10.2x 2018 operating profit, and demand for the asset was said to be high. Of the proceeds, c.£130m will be used to deleverage, and most of the remainder (c.£50m) will be returned to shareholders, albeit management has not yet decided if this will be via a buyback or special dividend. The c.£20m reduction to profit reflects Air Handling being the highest-margin division in the group (c.7% operating margin vs mid-single digit for others).

PBateman quiet.. everyone asleep still?
11:15 am
BE11:16am

Needs shareholder and regulatory approval so cash returns won't be until next year.

BE11:16am

Building Solutions disposal (c.£3-4m impact on 2019E PBT). This deal marks the final and eighteenth disposal as part of SIG's plan to dispose non-core assets contributing c.13% of group sales (as set out at the Nov-17 CMD). The cash consideration of £37.5m suggests a multiple of of 11.4x 2018 operating profit, and
subject to antitrust clearance, is expected to complete by end-2019E.

nightingale20201 morning all
BE11:17am

So -- earnings absolutely smashed but a lot of moving parts. Underlying PBT downgrade of about 15%.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

While today's announcements are likely to dilute PBT by c.50%, dilution to EPS is expected to be lower due to reduced interest costs and scope for share buybacks.

dinosaurjuice1 morning

While the challenging market backdrop does not come as a total surprise, the
extent of the deterioration does and the impact that it will have on our forecasts.
However, the disposals are welcome as it totally transforms the balance sheet and
leaves scope for a circa £50m return of cash to shareholders.

BE11:25am

 Prime Minister Johnson has finally recognized that his Brexit deal entails some uncomfortable trade-offs: we’re getting two borders for the price of one  Even though Johnson’s Brexit deal would only lead to limited checks, it is very hard to see why Europe/Ireland would eventually accept such a proposal. EU leaders gratefully accepted the UK’s concession of Northern Ireland alignment, but did not give one iota in return  Meanwhile, both the EU and the UK are treading carefully to avoid any blame when things go wrong and count on the UK Parliament to prevent a no-deal Brexit on October 31  The EU and the UK will continue talking in the run up to the Oct. 17-18 European Council, but the focus should be on Westminster  An election is inevitable and in the interest of each and every party in these negotiations, but it is far from certain that this will solve matters. The three-month extension to Article 50 that is currently being suggested by the Benn Act looks to be too tight. It’s hard to see the UK getting its act together before this deadline

LordByron HSBC analyst gone already?
cracklenpop Brexit deal there if political will is = NI stays in the CU as well as the SM, rest of UK leaves both, GFA honoured. Simples.
BE11:27am

11:27 am
BE11:27am

The odds of both a deal and a no-deal Brexit on October 31 have slimmed considerably, but the
outlook remains ever so murky. But we can draw a few conclusions:
1. The country is in uncharted waters. There is no script and nobody knows where the show is
going. Brexit is a huge clash between reality and deception, with no easy way out.
2. Both the EU and the UK are treading carefully to avoid any blame when things go wrong and
count on the UK Parliament to prevent a no-deal Brexit on October 31.
3. An election is inevitable and in the interest of each and every party in these negotiations, but
it is far from certain that this will solve matters.
4. The three-month extension to Article 50 that is currently being suggested by the Benn Act
looks to be very tight if an election needs to be organized in the meantime. Are three months
really enough for the UK to get its act together? We don’t think so.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Pizza Express bondholders are also reported to be preparing for a lively debate as to what their debt is worth. The group, which has a billion pounds worth of debt and counting, admittedly some of it to its own equity holders, has around two thirds of a billion pounds worth of third party secured bonds. Bloomberg reports that the August bonds are trading at 84p in the pound whilst the 2022 bonds are trading at 23p in the pound. Not prizes for guessing who the market expects to be taking a haircut.

BE11:37am

Back in June, Langton commented in its Premium Email that Pizza Express’ full year numbers (to 30 Dec 2018) included some ‘very large numbers and many of them are negative.’ We pointed out that ‘the group has £1.6m of debt per restaurant. Quite an achievement as leasehold restaurants may only cost a third of that to build.’

Tom Dalgleish Brexit beats talking about the weather
BE11:37am

urthermore, we said that Pizza Express ‘has 14x debt to EBITDA. Even for a company with a large number of freehold properties, this would be extremely high. For a leasehold company, it is almost intolerable.’ We added ‘40% of debt is owed to the parent company. As this is based in the Caymans, we have little detail as to how it is sourced.’ In the short term, it would appear that it is the 60% of debt held by third parties that is likely to be causing a headache.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Pizza Express's troubles tells us a lot more about PE than the sector.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

We downgrade outer year EBITDA margin forecasts to take a more prudent view on the likely outcome of the strategic review. We believe that a broad range of possible options are being considered. Our new forecasts allow for decisions to invest more in certain parts of the business. EPS forecasts drop 10-13% as a result. On our new low-in-range forecasts MCRO trades on a greater than 15% Oct-21 FCF yield and 8% dividend yield. We revise our price target down to 1,500p (DCF-derived, no M&A). We continue to believe that significant operational improvement can unlock value in the shares.

September volumes were decent overall, and Q3 should be supportive for the exchanges. We've nudged up numbers and our price objective for DB1 (to €151) and Euronext (€82). We like the exchanges, with LSE our strongest view; Refinitiv should be transformational and accretive.

When we looked at Flutter’s presentation last week it struck us that it would look very similar, apart from the colours, if it were GVC acquiring Stars instead of Flutter. There is probably too much debt. But debt will fall while the competition authorities do their work, so it seems worth discussing the possibilities.

Flutter has changed its management team since the merger of Betfair and Paddy (which took a while to bed in) so it is hard to know how it will fare with Stars and Sky.

The Becher's Brook sized hurdle is, however, the financing.

Mr Grumpy @BE Exactly.https://www.ft.com/content/b044ef66-db89-11e9-9c26-419d783e10e8
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

For our preliminary calculations, shown below, we have assumed that GVC pays a 10% premium to the implied value of Flutter’s offer in cash (paying C$32.80 per Stars share). This results in an eye-watering net debt/EBITDA ratio of over 7x and cash interest cover of barely 2x. Although, as a result of synergies and strong net cash generation, those ratios would improve rapidly thereafter.

BE12:02pm

It seems unlikely that a debt-financed cash offer could be achieved while GVC is on the public markets. But management has a track record in getting tricky deals done; perhaps some of the assets of the merged GVC/Stars entity could be sold to reduce debt, or perhaps the transaction could be completed off-market.
